Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: A sermon must be delivered for a High Holiday service, which the entire congregation is expected to attend.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my computer screen, headset pressing into my ear, the hum of the call center around me. My telemarketing shift was strict—every minute accounted for, every break scheduled. The compliance system watched us all, ready to flag any unscheduled pause. I glanced at the clock. In just an hour, I was supposed to be at the synagogue, standing before my congregation to deliver the High Holiday sermon I’d spent weeks preparing. They expected inspiration, guidance, a sense of community—especially today. But my shift didn’t end for another two hours, and if I left early, even by a few minutes, the system would log it. I could face disciplinary action, maybe even lose my job. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands: the congregation waiting for their rabbi, the supervisor monitoring every second of my telemarketing role. I felt pulled apart, the expectations of both worlds pressing in, and I didn’t know which part of myself I could let down.
